analysis.main_subject: Introduction to the seminar 'Switzerland in the Context of European Integration', outlining its dual focus on the historical and institutional foundations of the EU and the specific, complex relationship between Switzerland and the EU.
key_concepts: Territorial Structure of the EU (Enlargement & Differentiation)
Contemporary Crises and Future Development of the EU
Switzerland-EU Relations (historical development & areas of cooperation)
Linkage of Policy Knowledge to Bilateral Practice
Domestic Political Discourse (in CH and EU)

exam_relevance.reason: This document outlines the entire seminar's framework and core learning objectives. It defines the two main thematic blocks that will structure the course and, consequently, any comprehensive exam. Understanding these objectives is crucial for contextualizing all subsequent material and identifying key exam topics.

potential_exam_questions: Outline the two main thematic blocks of this seminar and explain their interconnection.
Describe the key dimensions for understanding European integration as presented in Block 1.
What are the core aspects for analyzing Switzerland-EU relations according to Block 2?
Discuss why the relationship between Switzerland and the EU can be characterized as 'increasingly difficult'.
How do 'domestic political discourses' in Switzerland and the EU influence their bilateral relationship?
analysis.summary: This is the foundational document for the seminar, setting the agenda for the entire course. It establishes a dual analytical framework: first, understanding the EU's genesis, institutions, law, and current challenges, and second, applying this knowledge to the specific, politically sensitive case of Swiss-EU relations. Mastery of this introductory structure is essential for organizing all subsequent learning and exam preparation.
